image.altText: A young woman looks into the camera unsmiling, she is sat on a rattan chair next to a pot plant.

props.synopsis: Young people relocating interstate for work or study is a familiar story in Tasmania. New research shows those who leave the island state are better off when it comes to work and education outcomes.

title.children: Why young Tasmanians who move to the mainland are better off

image.altText: A group of people waving flags

props.synopsis: Beijing despises the winner of Taiwan's election, Lai Ching-tei, calling him a separatist and a troublemaker. But it can't ignore the message voters are sending with his victory, writes Kathleen Calderwood.Â

title.children: Taiwan just had an election, and the outcome is everything Beijing was dreading

image.altText: Patients being treated at the Royal Melbourne Hospital road trauma unit.

props.synopsis: Last year was the deadliest on Australia's roads in five years, but there's no national record of how many people were left injured.

title.children: Kate works at one of Australia's busiest hospitals. Road injuries represent a 'huge chunk' of its cases

image.altText: Posing for a photo on a tree-lined dirt track, two men press their hands against the belly of a pregnant woman who is smiling

props.synopsis: The Pope's recent pronouncement against surrogacy has sparked heated global debate about the controversial issue. In Australia, surrogacy is complex: deplored by some but embraced by others whose lives have been transformed by remarkable acts of generosity and love.

title.children: Anna, Matt and Brendan's surrogacy journey blossomed into a lifelong celebration. For other surrogates, everything went wrong

image.altText: Portrait of a lady in a pink high-vis vest looking at the camera.

image.altText: Left to right: Ben Shelton, Jannik Sinner, Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Sebastian Korda.

props.synopsis: Father time comes for everyone. Except it seems for Novak Djokovic but even the Serbian great can't stave off generation after generation forever and now could be their time to do the seemingly impossible.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of Palestinian Australians are waiting for family members with approved visas to get a green light from border officials to leave Gaza.

title.children: Israa's family have been granted visas to Australia, but she worries every day if they will make it out of Gaza alive

image.altText: A man in a tux and a woman in a blush gown and tiara

props.synopsis: When Crown Prince Frederik and his Australian-born wife Princess Mary ascend the throne overnight, it will be a simple, pared-back affair. But it's all part of a centuries-long effort to keep the Danish monarchy going.Â

image.altText: Scott and Vicki hold coffee cups in a kitchen. They are smiling for the camera.

image.altText: water over double-lane highway

props.synopsis: Authorities remind the public constantly that floodwaters and cars don't mix, but drivers continue to take the risk. Here's what experts say about why people do it.

title.children: After more than 50 swift-water rescues in Victoria this week, why do people keep driving into floods?

image.altText: Maldivian resort

title.children: Why is India turning the screws on a tiny island neighbour?

image.altText: Penny Wong covers a microphone while speaking to a government official

image.altText: A snake dangles from an ice dispenser on a fridge door.

title.children: 'Enough to send a chill down anyone's spine': Snake found dangling down from ice dispenser on fridge door

image.altText: a young african man sitting behind weights at a gym

image.altText: An old brick building at night with lights on inside.

image.altText: A woman with dark hair and wearing a hat sits in an aeroplane.

props.synopsis: From an alleged poisoning plot to uprooted royals on the run and a secret romance that divided a family, these are just a few accounts of Australia's royal encounters.
